titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the William Henry Grimes papers, 1845-1884
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Rubenstein Staff; EAD finding aid derived from MARC record using marc2ead_sectionA.xsl

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid derived from MARC record via marc2ead_sectionA.xsl, May 2019

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.abstract: Collection consists of personal correspondence of William Henry Grimes. Topics include his unsuccessful courtship with Sallie Seymour and her later marriage to Mr. Randolph; prices of commodities and buggies in the 1850s; conditions during the American invasion of Mexico, 1847, including troop movements in Jalapa and the hanging of two Americans for the murder of a Mexican boy; and an 1861 discussion of secession and Western Maryland politics.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.p: William Henry Grimes Papers, 1845-1884, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.p: This finding aid was derived from a MARC record using a crosswalk defined in marc2ead_sectionA.xsl. The finding aid was generated as part of a larger project to digitize several thousand small collections housed in Section A, May 2019.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: William Henry Grimes was a doctor in Sharpsburg, Washington Co., Maryland.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of personal correspondence of William Henry Grimes. Topics include his unsuccessful courtship with Sallie Seymour and her later marriage to Mr. Randolph; prices of commodities and buggies in the 1850s; conditions during the American invasion of Mexico, 1847, including troop movements in Jalapa and the hanging of two Americans for the murder of a Mexican boy; and an 1861 discussion of secession and Western Maryland politics.
